did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.unittitle:
Recordings of University of Virginia Events
1975-1985
did.physdesc: This collection consists of 289 recordings (24 cassette tapes, 166 5-inch audio reels and 99 7-inch audio reels.)

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Recordings of University of Virginia Events, Accession #RG-4/2/9.961, Special Collections, University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Archival transfer fromUniversity of Virginia Information Services, 1996 August 13.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection contains recordings of speeches and interviews by or with Bella Abzug, Richard A. Beaumont, Ray Bice, James Boren, George Bowles, Robert Caneveri, Irby Cauthen, John Chafee, the Dalai Lama, Ernest Ern, Gerald Ford, Mills Godwin, Sheldon Hackney, Bruce P. Hayden, Frank, Hereford, Chaim Herzog, Luther Hodges, A. E. Dick Howard, Hugh P. Kelly, Bowie Kuhn, Bert Lance, Dumas Malone, Frederick Nichols, Merrill Peterson, J. Kenneth Robinson, B.F.D. Runk, Hugh Scott, Thomas Storrs, Kwame Ture, and Stansfield Turner.

Topics on the tapes include acid rain, adolescent suicide, career planning, civil rights and Martin Luther King, Jr., Halley's comet, mainstreaming handicapped children, Iran, nuclear energy, the Panama Canal Treaty, senior citizen fitness, Virginia's weather and climate.

Many topics pertain to the University of Virginia including athletics, capital campaign, convocation (1981), finals (1980), founders day, the Good Old Song, the honor system, intramural and recreational sports, Thomas Jefferson, and rare books.

scopecontent.p: I. Sort of in honor of Valentine's Day, a sweetheart of a cardiologist looks at hearts from an unsentimental angle. II. Tony Sanchez of Laredo used to pick up coal on the railroad tracks to heat his hovel. Finally he's warm and rich because he has gas. III. How do you make the most of your evanescent stardom or notoriety? You try to get Mark McCormack to take you on as a client. IV. He wouldn't say so because he's too young to retire, but Tom Casey, a disaster expert, ranks politicians among the major hazards. V. How about whimsical paintings to liven up a wall or storefront? Greg Brown of Palo Alto has proved they're a good idea. [from cue sheet in case] Week of February 13. 0040
